awd_titl_txt: NETS: SMALL: Fault and Performance Management in Carrier-Grade Virtual Networks Over Multiple Clouds
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to carry out research leading to the development of an intelligent fault, configuration and performance management framework for virtual carrier networks. The research activity will consider improvements to the management framework in a multiple cloud setting so that the high availability and resiliency requirements of carrier grade networks can be realized. To accomplish this objective,
the project team will apply novel Machine Learning (ML) algorithms to perform network fault detection and isolation.

The research activity has 3 main thrusts: 1) adapting classical machine learning algorithms to target a very dynamic, distributed and real-time environment; 2) developing deductive-predictive fault and performance detection and localization techniques; and 3) developing a hybrid 'central-distributed' technique for training the machine learning models. A key project outcome is to enhance understanding of how Network Function Virtualization (NFV) management, cloud management and operations support can leverage machine learning. The research team will develop new techniques for training machine learning models, and a testbed will be developed to validate the approach.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

We carried out research leading to the development of an intelligent fault, configuration and performance management framework for virtual carrier networks on multiple clouds so that they fulfill high availability and resiliency requirement of carrier grade networks. We worked mainly on the following four aspects:

1. AI-enabled virtual network services on multi-cloud based carrier networks:

The main objective of this activity was to understand how AI-based techniques can help in fault detection and localization to take such services closer to the performance and availability of the traditional networks.

2. Efficient and Secure network slice provisioning:

Network slicing in 5G is expected to essentially change the way in which network operators deploy and manage vertical services with different performance requirements. Efficient and secure slice provisioning algorithms are important since network slices share the limited resources of the physical network

3. . Explainable AI:

Researchers and industrial leaders have difficulty explaining the decisions that sophisticated AI algorithms come up with because they cannot fully understand why and how these “black boxes” make their decisions

4. Evaluation Metric for Machine Learning Models of Security Applications:

Two requirements should be considered to evaluate an ML model built for a security application. First, given that attack and benign activities have different effects on the systems, their mistakes should not be treated equally. Second, correctly classifying a sample in a class should not be the same as a mistake made by misclassifying in the same class. We proposed a safety score as an evaluation metric tailored for cost-sensitive security applications.

The project resulted in three Ph.D. theses, several journal papers. Two graduate students have joined academia and one has joined the industry - all working of different aspects of AI to different problems.

Broader Impact:

A reliable and economical software defined infrastructure (SDI) would improve adoption of the cloud-based virtual network deployment. This would benefit customers in the form of innovative telecom services at a lower cost. With improved performance of these networks distributed real-time services of mass welfare like remote healthcare would be able to work reliably on these.
